newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil cenbank sees fiscal improvement in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Brazil cenbank sees fiscal improvement in 1997.

text.p: Brazil's Central Bank expects to see steady improvement in the public sector's fiscal health during 1997, said Altamir Lopes, head of the bank's economics department.
Lopes told reporters that the accounts of all parts of the public sector had showed a "tendency to recover" in the second half of 1996 and that this trend should continue.

"The picture started off a bit foggy, but in the second half began to show a tendency to recover," he said after announcing the public sector operational deficit was an unexpectedly low 3.89 percent of GDP last year.
"The expectation is that this trend of improvement will continue," Lopes added.
He acknowledged that some states and municipalities had withheld 13th month salary payments until early 1997.

This may have contributed to a reduction in the states and cities' primary deficit to 0.57 percent of GDP in December from 0.69 percent of GDP in November. In 1995, the states and municipalities posted a primary deficit of 0.17 percent.
Lopes said some states had carried out extensive voluntary redundancy programs which had carried high one-off costs.
